content.value: Cron is a Linux scheduling system that allows users to run commands or scripts automatically at specified times or intervals.

Many system tasks need to be performed regularly, such as backups, log cleanup, system updates, and monitoring. Manually running these tasks is inefficient and error-prone. Cron allows Linux to execute tasks automatically without user interaction, saving time and ensuring reliability.
A cron job is a scheduled task that runs automatically according to a defined time and date.
crontab is a file and command used to create, view, edit, and manage cron jobs.

content.description: Lists all cron jobs for the current user.

content.value: Editing cron jobs allows users to add or modify scheduled tasks.
A cron job uses five time fields followed by the command to execute. Each field represents a specific unit of time.
